children.subject:
No. You don't even need a college degree to get hired in some software jobs. Experience is more important. If you can get your boss to pay for a Masters latter on, great.

For grad school (at least in the US), you don't need a Masters to get accepted into PHd programs. Although completion of a PHd might give you a Masters for free along the way.

history.content:
No. For most software engineering jobs, as posted below, a bachelors (and sometimes even no degree!) is enough. https://career.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/pdf/Survey/2018ComputerScience.pdf This is the career destination survey from 2018, where over half of the CS majors who graduated responded. Most (~80%) were employed with just an undergraduate degree. A lot less when onto grad school.

For some more specialized roles, like doing Machine Learning/Data science in industry masters seems to make you a lot more competitive. This has a nice perspective https://towardsdatascience.com/do-you-need-a-graduate-degree-for-data-science-8e3d0ef39253 

To your last question about working a few years then getting a masters - some employers will pay you to get a masters degree! Which seems awesome.

Hi friends,

I am currently a freshman in L&S who is thinking about majoring in CS and/or Data Science. I really like the materials, but at this point I am not planning to go to grad school because I am so done with all the exams. I am thinking about getting a job with a BA degree in CS, which I heard is practical. However, I have also heard that many tech-related jobs require a minimum of a Master's Degree in the relevant field. Is this true in general for the industry? And if it is, do I have the option of working for a few years, and then going back for a master's degree depending on my situation? Any advice would be very much appreciated!

Thanks a lot!
history.subject: Is a master's degree necessary for cs major?

history.content:
Hi friends,

I am currently a freshman in L&S who is thinking about majoring in CS and/or Data Science. I really like the materials, but at this point I am not planning to go to grad school because I am so done with all the exams. I am thinking about getting a job with a BA degree in CS, which I heard is practical. However, I have also heard that many tech-related jobs require a minimum of a Master's Degree in the relevant field, or the career track would be significantly shortened without one. Is this true in general for the industry? And if it is, do I have the option of working for a few years, and then going back for a master's degree depending on my situation? Any advice would be very much appreciated!

Thanks a lot!
history.subject: Is a master's degree necessary for cs major?
